div.p:
XXIX 310
Robinson I explained to them again
& again that when it was
said we came out of the
49 sea it did not mean that
we came from beneath
the water - but the fiction
was too pleasant and I
believe when I was out
of hearing my men always
represented themselves
as led by a genuine
specimen of the he mermaids "Just see his
hair"!

As the strangers had wooly
hair like themselves I had
n to give up the idea of meeting
anything more European
than two cross breed Portuguese
engaged in trading for
slaves and other articles
ivory and beesbees' wax -

On theThe 16th weafter a short
march we came to a most
lovely valley about a mile
& a half ^ wide and stretching away
Eastwards ^ up to a ^ low prolongation of
Monakadzi - A small
stream meanders down the
socentre of this pleasant green
glen and on a little rill
which flows into it from
the Southern side Western side
stands the town of Kabompo
or as he likes best to be called Shinté
311
When Manenko thought the sun
was high enough for us
50 to make a lucky entrance
we found the town embowered
in tropical trees having great
expansion
of leaf and bananas
The streets are straight - andd
present such a ^ complete contrast
to those of the Bechuanas which are
all very tortuous - Here
too we first saw native
huts with square walls
and round roofs - The
fences hedges or walls of the courts
which surround the huts
are wonderfully straight and
built made of straightupright poles
a few inches apart and ^ strong grass
or leafy bushes neatly woven
between - In the courts were
little plantations of tobacco
a little solanaceous plant
which the Balonda use
as a relish and sugar cane
and bananas - Many of
the poles have grown again
and trees of the Ficus indica
family have been planted
around in order to give
to the inhabitants a grateful
shade - They regard it with
with some sort of veneration
as a medicine or charm -
312
Goats were browsing about
and when we made our
51 appearance a crowd of negroes
all fully armed ran towards
as if they would eat us
up - Some had guns but
the manner in which
they were held shewedshowed that the
owners were more used
to bows and arrows than
than white man's weapons -
After surrounding and looking
staring at us for an hour
they began to disperse

The two African Portuguese
(crossbreeds) of whom we had
heard, had erected a little
encampment opposite ours
the place where ours was
about to be made - One
of them whose spine had been
injured in youth, a rare
sight in this country came
and visited us, and I
returned the visit next morning
His tall His companion a tall yellow
had that sickly hue yellow
hue which made him
look fairer than myself
but his head was covered
with a ^ crop mat of un-mistakeableunmistakable
wool - They had a gang
of young female slaves
in a chain hoeing the
313
ground in front of their
encampment to clear it
52 of weeds & grass - They seemed
to have were purchased
recently in Lobale whence they
the traders had now come - There
were many Mambari with
them and the establishment
was conducted with that
military order which pervades
all the arrangements of
the Portuguese colonists - A
drum was beat and trumpet
sounded at certain hours quite
in military fashion - It was
the first time most of my
men had seen menslaves in
chains - "They are not men ^ (meaning they
are beasts)
who treat their children so"

The Balonda are real
negroes having much more
wool on their heads and
bodies than any of the Bechuanas
or Caffre tribes - They are
generally very dark in colour
and from among them
have been drawn many of
the slaves whioch have
been exported to Brazil - But
while they have ga general
similarity to the typical negro
I amnever could nevfrom
my observation of them think
that we have ^ our ideal negro
seen in Tobacconiststobacconists' shops is the true type
314
A large proportion of the Balonda
have heads elongated somewhat
53 upwards backwards & upwards
thick lips - flat noses
elongated ossa calces &c &c - but
there are so many good
looking well shaped heads
and persons among them
that ^ hating except for the inclination
to thick lips I thought that
Ethnologists have gone
very much on the principle
of comparing the very
ugliest specimens of
of the black races with
the verythe most beautiful
specimens among ourselves

17th Tuesday We were honoured with
a grand reception by Shinte about
one oclocko'clock - Sambanza claimed the
honour of presenting meus Manenko
being ^ slightly indisposed - The Native Portuguese
and Mam[bariMambari went fully armed with
guns in order to give Shinte a a
203 parting salute - They had their drummer
and higher trumpeter making as
315
much noise as very old instruments would
yield - tThe kotla or place of
audience was about a hundred
54 yards square and two graceful
specimens of the ficus indica
stood near one end - Under one
of these sat Shinte on a sort of
throne covered with a leopard's
skin; He had on a checked jacket
and kilt of scarlet baize edged
with green. - Many strings of
large beads hung from his
neck and his limbs were
covered with iron & copper
armlets and bracelets - On his
head he wore a hellmet made of
beads woven neatly together &
crowned with a great bunch
of goose feathers - close to him
sat three lads
with great
sheaves of
arrows over
their shoulders As we entered
the kotla the party of Manenko clapped
their hands vigorously as a
salutation to Shinte

p.del:
Behind him sat eighty or one
hundred women

div.p:
When we entered the kotla wethe
whole party of Manenko saluted
Shinte him by clapping their hands &
Sambanza did obeisance by
rubbing his chest & arms
with ashes - - One of the trees
being unoccupied I retreated to it
for the sake of the shade and
my whole party did the same
we were now about forty yards
from the chief and gcould see
316
the whole ceremony - The different
sections of the tribe came
forward in the same way ^ that we
55 did the headman making obeizanceobeisance
with ashes which he carried
with him for the purpose - Then
came the soldiers all armed to the
teeth running and shouting
towards us - ^ with their swords drawn and their faces screwed
up so as to appear as savage
as possible for the purpose
I thought of trying whether they
could not make us take to
our heels - As we sdid not they
turned round towards Shinte
and saluted him then retired
When all had come and were
seated then began the curious
capering usually seen in peechos
A man starts up and imitates
the most approved d attitudes
observed in actual fight
sh Throwing the javelin - recievingreceiving
another in the shield, springing
to one side to avoid another
running backwards or forwards
Sp leaping &c - Here - the spokesman
of Nyamoana and Sambanza
stalked backwards & forwards
in front of Shinte and gave
forth in a loud voice all
they had been able to learn
either from ourselves or
people of our past history
317
and connection with the Makololo
the return of the captives - The wish
56 to open the country to trade - The
bibleBible as a word from heaven
the white mansman's desire to live in
for the tribes to live in peace -
ought to have taught the Makololo
that first for the Balonda never
attacked them yet they attacked
had assailed ^ the Balonda - perhaps he is
fibbing perhaps not - They rather
thought he was - But as the
Balonda had good hearts and
Shinte had never done any harm
to any one he had better recievereceive
the white man him well and send him on
his way. - Sambanza was
gaillygaily attired and abesides a
profusion of beads had a
cloth so long ^ that a boy carried it
after him as a train

Behind Shinte sat about
a hundred women clothed in
their best, which best happened
to be a profusion of red blaize
The chief wife of Shinte one of the
MatibeleMatebele or
ZulausZulus sat
in front with a curious
red cap on
her head : S During the intervals
between the speeches these ladies
burst forth into a sort
of plaintive ditty but it was
impossible for any of us
to catch whether it was in
praise of the speaker, of Shinte
or of themselves - This was
318
the first time I had ever seen
women present in a public assembly
57 In the South the women were
not permitted to enter the Kotla
and when invited to come
to a religious service there
would not enter untilluntil
ordered to do so by the chief - but
here they expressed approbation
by clapping their hands and
laughing to different speakers
and Shinte frequently turned
round and spoke to them

A party of Musicians consisting of three drummers
and four
performers on the piano went
round the Kotla chiefseveral times
regaling us with their music
The drums are neatly carved
from the trunk of a tree &
have a small hole in the
side covered with a bit of
spidersspider's web - The Ends are
covered with the skin of an
antelope ^ pegged on and when they
wish to beat tighten it they
hold it to the fire to make
it contract - They instruments are beaten
with the hands

Morimba The piano named Marimba
consists of two bars of wood
placed side by
side (here quite straight but farther
North bent round so as to resemble
half the tire of a carriage wheel
319
across these are placed about
fifteen keys each of which is
58 two or three inches broad &
fourfifteen or eighteen inches long,
their thickness is regulated
according to the deepness of
the note required - Each of
the keys has a calabash
beneath it a part being cut
off the upper part of which
to enable it to embrace the
fobars and form ^ hollow sounding-
-boards hollows to the keys - They too
are of different sizes according
to the key, and the keys
are used little drumsticks
? elicit the notes - Rapidity of
execution seems much
admired among ^ them and the
music so is pleasant to
the ear - In Angola the
Portuguese use the Marimba
in their dances -

Cross When nine speakers
had concluded their speechesorations
Shinte stood up and so did
all the people - He had maintained
true African dignity of manner
all the while, but my people
remarked that he never took
his eyes off me for a moment
About a thousand people were
present according to my
calculation and about three
hundred soldiers - The sun had
320
now become hot and the scene
ended by the Mambari discharging
59 their guns.

18th On Wedends We were awakedawakened
during the night by a messenger
from Kabompo Shinte requesting
ata visit at a very unseasonable
hour - As I was just in
the sweating stage of an intermittent
and the path to the town lay
through a wet valley, I declined
going - Kolimbota who knows
their customs best urged
me to go but independantindependent
of sickness I hated words of the
night - my and deeds of
darkness - "I was neither
a hyaenahyena not a witch"
Kolimbota thought we ought to
conform to their wishes
in everything I thought we
ought to have some wishchoice
in the matter as well, which
put him into high dudgeon -
However at ten next
morning we went and
were led into the courts
of Shinte ^ the walls of
woven rods all very neat and
high - Many trees stood
within the inclosures and afforded
a grateful shade - These are
planted by man for we saw
some recently put in with
grass wound round the trunk
to protect them from the Sun -
321
The otherwise waste corners ^ of the streets were
planted with sugar cane and
60 bananas which spread their
large light leaves over the walls

The Ficus indica, tree under
which we sat, had very large
leaves but shewedshowed its relationship
to the Indian Banian by sending
down shoots towards the
ground - Shinte soon came
and appeared a man of
upwards of forty fifty ^ five years
of age of frank and open
countenance - Heand and about the
middle height - He seemed in
good ⎡humour and said he
Chester had expected yesterday that
a man who came from
the Ggods would have come
approached and talked to him
That had been my own
intention in going to the reception
but when we came & saw
the formidable preparations
and all his own men keeping
at least forty yards off from
him, I ^ yielded to the representations
solicitations of my men and
remained atunder by the tree - ^ opposite to that under
which he sat This
remark confirmed my previous
belief that a frank open
fearless manner is the most
winning with all these Africans
I stated the object of my
journey and mission
322
and to all I advanced the old gentleman
61 clapped his hands in approbation
He replied through a spokesman
then all the company joined
in the response by clapping of hands too

After the more serious
business was over I asked
if he had ever seen a white
man before - He replied "never
you are I was the very first heI hadve seen
with a white skin and straight
hair - your clothing too is
different from any we have
ever seen too" - They had been
visited by Native Portuguese
(crossbreeds) and Mambari
alonly - He presented

I haOn learning from some
of the people that "Shinte's
mouth was bitter for want
of tasting ox flesh" I presented
him with one of to his
great delight and as his
country is so well adapted
for them advised him to
begin a trade in cows
with the Makololo - He was
pleased with the idea and
when we returned ^ from LoandoLuanda
we found that he had
profited by the hint for he
had got three and one
of them justified my opinion
of the country for it was
more like a prize hieferheifer for
fatness then any we had
323
seen in Africa - He soon
afterwards sent us a basket
62 of green maize boiled - another
of manioc meal and a
small fowl - The maize
shewsshows by its size the fertility
of the black soil of all the
valleys here and so does
the manioc though no manure
is ever applied - We saw
Manioc attain a height of six
feet & upwards and this
is a plant which requires
the very best soil

During this time
Manenko had been very busy
with all her people in
getting up a very pretty hut
and court yard - to be as
she said her residence
always when white men
where were brought by
her along the same path
When she heard that we
had given an ox to her
uncle she came forward
to us with the
air of one
wronged and explained that "this
was her white man, she
had brought him here and
that therefore the ox was
hers not Shinte's - She took
She ordered her
men to
bring it she got it slaughtered by her
own people ^ by them and presented
her uncle with a leg only
324
This is mentioned exactly as it
happened and Shinte did not
63 seem at all annoyed by the
occurrence

19th I was awakedawakened ^ at an early ^ hour by
a messenger from Shinte
but I had just got the thirst
of a raging fever asuagedassuaged by
the bursting forth of a copious
perspiration ^ and declined
going for
a few hours - Violent action
of the heart all the way to
the town did not predispose
me to be patient with the
delay which occurred probably
on account of the divination
being unfavourable - "They
could not find Shinte" When
I returned to bed another message
was recievedreceived "Shinte wished
to say all he had to tell mesay at
once" - This was too tempting
an offer so hewe went & he
had a fowl ready ^ in his hand to present
a calabas a basket of manioc
meal and a calabash of
mead - Referring to the
constantly ^ every recurring attacks of
fever he remarked that
was the only thing which
would prevent my reaching
LoandoLuanda for he a successful
issue to my journey for
he had a guide men to give
me who knew all the paths
325
which led to the white men
He had himself travelled far
64 as a young man - On asking
what he would recommend
for the fever, "Drink plenty
of the mead and as it gets
in it will drive the fever
out" - It was rather strong, and
I suspect he likes the remedy
pretty well even though he has
no fever - He had always
been a friend to Sebituane
and now that his son ^ Sekeletu was
in his place he ^ Shinte was not
a friend but a Sekeletu's father
to him, and if a son asks a favour
the father must do it give
it - He was highly pleased
with the large calabashes of
clarified butter and fat
which Sekeletu had sent him
and wished to detain Kolimbota
that he might send a present
back to Sekeletu by his
hands - This proposition
we afterwards discovered
was Kolimbota's own as
he heard so much about
the ferocity of the tribes
inthrough which we were
to pass that he wished to
save his skin - As will
be seen further on he
was the only one of our
party to returned with a wound

326
Dennett We were particularly
struck in passing through
the village with the punti
65 punctiliousness of manners
shewnshown by the Balonda -
The inferiors on meeting
their superiors in the street
at once drop on their knees,
and rub dust on their arms
and chest:, cont They continue
the salutation ^ of clapping their hands untilluntil the
great ones have passed;
TSambanzaSambanza knelt down
in this manner till the
Son of Shinte had passed him

We several times saw
the woman, who occupies the
position of drawer of water
for Shinte -, she rings a
bell as she passes along
to give warning to all to
keep out of her way;
It would be a grave offence
for any one to come near
her, and exercise an evil
influence by his presence
ofn the drink of the chief
I suspect that offences
of the slightest character
among the poor are
made the pretext for
selling them tor their children
to the Mambari - for a
young man of Lobale had
327
fled into the country of Shinte
and located himself without
66 shewingshowing himself to the chief;
This was considered an
offence sufficient to warrant
his being seized and offered
for sale while we were
there; - He had not reported
himself so they did not know
the reason of his running
away from his own chief; - and that chief might
accuse himthem of recievingreceiving
a criminal - It was
curious to notice the effect
of the slave trade in blunting
the moral susceptibility:
No chief in the South would
treat a fugitive in this way -
mMy men were horrified at
the act even though old Shinte
and his counsel had some
shewshow of reason on their side And both the
Barotse & the
Makololo
declared that
if the Balonda
only knew
of the policy
pursued by
them to
fugitives but
few would
remain long
with their
present chief
Shinte - They
My men excited
the wonder of
this people by
stating that
every one of
them had a
cow at least in
his possession

Another incident which
occurred while we were here
many be mentioned as totally
unknown in the South
Two children, ^ of between 7 & 8 years, went out ^ to collect firewood a short
distance from their parents
home ^ which was a quarter of a mile - from the village, and were kidnapped;
The distracted parents could not
find a trace of them - This
happened so close to the town,
where there are no beasts of prey,
that we I suspect some of the
high men of Shinte's court
67 328
must have been the guilty parties,
They can sell them by night The Mambari
erect large
huts of a
square
shape to stow
these stolen
ones in -
They are welled
fed, but
aired by
night only - ;
The frequent
p kidnapping
from outlying
hamlets
explains the
stocadesstockades
we saw
around them
The parents
have no
redress, for
even
and Shinte himself seems
fond of working in the dark
One night he sent for me,
though I always stated I liked
all my dealings to be above-
-board: When I went he
presented me with a slave
girl about ten years old - He
said he had always been
in the habit of presenting his
visitors with a child - On
my thanking him, and saying
that I thought it wrong
to take away children from their
parents, - that I wished him
to give up this system altogether,
and trade in cattle, ivory, and
beesbees' wax - , he urged that she
was to be a child to me bring
me water, and that a ^ great man
ought to have a child for the
purpose yet I had none - The
As I mentioned that I had four
children, and would be very
sorry if my chief would take
my little girl and give her
away, and that I would
prefer this child to remain
and comfo carry water for
her own mother; - he thought
I was dissatisfied with her
the size, and sent for one
329
68 a head taller - This, withAfter many
explanations of how we detest
slavery, and how displeasing
it must be to God to see his
children selling each other as
and giving each other, so much
grief as this child's mother
must feel, I declined her
also. - If but I could have taken
her with my family & instructed
for the purpose
of instruction, her for a time and then
returned her as a free woman,
according to a promise I should
have made to the parents,
I might have done so; - But
to take her away, and probably
never be able to secure her
return would have produced
no good effect on the
minds of the Balonda - They
would not as I taught
themn have seen evidence
of the existence of of our hatred to
slavery - And the kind attentions
of my friends, would, as it
almost always does in s
similar heacases, have turned
the poor thing's her head - The difference in
position between them and us
is as great as between the
the lowest and highest among
in England; ^ ourselves - and we know
the effects of sudden elevation
on wiser heads than hers, whose
owners have not been born to it -
69 330
Shinte was most anxious
to see the pictures of the Magick
Lantern; - But fever had
so such a weakening an effect
and there was such violent
action of the heart with
buzzing in the ears, I
could not go for several
days - wWhen I went I did
go for the purpose he
had his principal men,
and the same crowd
of court beauties around
near him as at the reception.
The first picture exhibited
was Abraham ^ knife in hand about to
slaughter Isaac his son
Isaac; - It was shewnshown
as large as life, and
the uplifted knife was
in the act of striking
the lad; - The ^ Balonda men
remarked it was much
likermore like a god than the
things of wood or
clay they worshipped -
I explained that this
was the first of a race
to whom God had given
the bibleBible we h now held,
and that among the his
children Our Saviour
appeared - The ladies
listened with awe; - When
70 331
I moved that slide the uplifted
dagger moved towards them,
& they thought - it was to
be sheathed in their bodies
instead of Isaac's. "Mother
Mother"! they all shouted
at once; and off they rushed
helter skelter, tumbling pell
mell over each other, and
the little idol huts and
tobacco bushes; - We could
not get ^ one of them back again
Shinte, however, sat bravely
through the whole, and examined
with interest the instrument
afterwards - An explanation
was always added after
each time of shewingshowing
its powers, so that no
one should imagine there
was aught supernatural
in it, and had Mr Murray
who kindly brought it
from England seen its
popularity among both
Makololo and Balonda
he would not have
regretted the direction his
generosity then took, - It was
the only mode of instruction
I was ever pressed to
repeat or that they
came long distances for
the express purpose of
both seeing & hearing

71 332
One cannot get away
quickly from these chiefs,
they like to have - the honour
of strangers residing in
their villages, - here we
had an additional cause
of delay in frequent
rains - twenty four hours
never elapsed without
heavy showers; - Everything
is affected by the
dampness, - Surgical instruments
become all rusty, - clothing
mildewed and shoes shoes
mouldy - My little tent
was - now so rotten
and full of small holes
that every heavy shower
caused a fine mist
to des-cenddescend on my blankedblanket
and make me fain
to cover methe head with
it - Heavy dews lay on
everything in the morning
even inside the tent,
And there is only a short
time of sunshine in the
afternoon so interrupted
by thunder showers that
we cannot dry our
bedding

p.seg:
The winds coming
from the North balways
bring heavy clouds & rain

In the South the only heavy rains
noticed are those which
come from the North East,
or East, - The thermometer
falls as low as 72˚ when
there is ^ no sunshine, though ^ when it is fair
generally as high as 82˚
(the thermometer (protected) throughout the
even in the mornings & evenings

div.p:
24th We expected to have started
today but Sambanza, who
had been sent off early
in the morning for guides,
returned at midday
without them and drunk,
This was the first case of
real babbling intoxication
we had seen in the country
The Boyaloa, of the or beer,
of the country possesses
more of a stupifyingstupefying
than exciting power, hence
the beer bibersbibbers are often
great sleepers-; They may
frequently ^ be seen sleeping lying on
their faces sound asleep; This
peculiarity ^ of posture was ascribed by
no less an authority than
Aristotle to wine, - while those
who were sent asleep by beer
were believed "to lie upon
their backs"
